elements.title: Southern chivalry (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that American abolitionists co-opted the concept of Southern chivalry (caricature pictured) as an insult against pro-slavery white Southerners?

elements.title: Shagdarjavin Natsagdorj (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Shagdarjavin Natsagdorj's remarks at an academic conference led to a communist purge and contributed to the Sino-Soviet split?

elements.title: Pujol (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Pujol and Quintonil are the highest-rated restaurants in Mexico's first Michelin guide, with two Michelin stars each?

elements.title: Peter Bowden (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that football player Peter Bowden only started long snapping to help his cousin, a punter, produce film in high school, and both are now in the National Football League?

elements.title: Jennings (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the adjacent Jennings and Sloane Houses comprise New York City's largest single-family residence?

elements.title: Arthur Fulton (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Arthur Fulton was a sniper in the First World War and described as "the most famous rifle shot the world has ever known"?

elements.title: Asyikin–Brugman Treaty (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Asyikin–Brugman Treaty was revoked 11 days after being signed?

elements.title: Shirley Warde (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Shirley Warde not only starred in theater and movie productions, but also wrote playscripts and short stories for magazines?

elements.title: a procession to ask for rain (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in Thailand and Cambodia, cats are used in a procession to ask for rain?
